title: Authors and Citation
text: Li W (2024). autovi: Auto visual inference computer vision models. https://tengmcing.github.io/autovi/, https://github.com/TengMCing/autovi/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {autovi: Auto visual inference with computer vision models},   author = {Weihao Li},   year = {2024},   note = {https://tengmcing.github.io/autovi/, https://github.com/TengMCing/autovi/}, }

what: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
title: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
text: Buja et al. (2009) provides inferential framework assess whether residual plots indeed contain visual patterns inconsistent model assumptions. However, unlike conventional statistical tests can performed computationally statistical software, lineup protocol requires human evaluation images. characteristic makes less suitable large-scale applications, given associated high labour costs time requirements. autovi package aims offer tools automated visual inference residual plots. Currently, supports diagnostic checks classical normal linear regression models (CNLRM), underlying computer vision models specifically trained model class. However, autovi API designed extensible model types. means can obtain predictions long provide appropriate method generating null residuals null_method argument.

title: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
text: can install development version autovi like :
code: remotes::install_github("TengMCing/autovi")

title: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
text: available trained Keras models listed list_keras_models(). trained Keras models listed predict visual signal strength visual patterns input residual plot. visual signal strength essentially approximation Kullback–Leibler divergence based distance metric quantifies difference actual residual distribution reference residual distribution assumed correct model specification. Details methodologies provided draft paper https://github.com/TengMCing/auto_residual_reading/blob/master/paper/paper.pdf. Different Keras models trained residual plots obtained different linear regression models violating various model assumptions. vss_32, vss_64 vss_128 trained residual plots containing visual patterns indicating non-linearity heteroskedasticity issues. number model name represents size input image. instance, 32 means input image 32times32 pixels. vss_phn_32, vss_phn_64 vss_phn_128 also trained residual plots containing visual patterns indicating non-linearity heteroskedasticity, visual patterns complex. Additionally, residual plots visual patterns non-normality also used models.
code: library(tidyverse) library(autovi) list_keras_models() %>% pull(model_name) #> [1] "vss_32"      "vss_64"      "vss_128"     "vss_phn_32"  "vss_phn_64"  #> [6] "vss_phn_128"

title: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
text: example, using vss_phn_32 Keras model. model can obtained using get_keras_model(). illustrate use package, use visage package define data generating process use incorrectly specified model fit 300 simulated observations. residual plot fitted model shows “S” shape indicating non-linearity issue.  run diagnostics fitted model, can initialize checker using auto_vi() look input residual plot using plot_resid() method.  predict visual signal strength residual plot, simply use vss() method. visual signal strength residual plot usually insufficient determine model correctly specified. Thus, need evaluate null residual plots comparison. checker includes default method generate null residuals consistent null hypothesis fitted model correctly specified, rotate_resid() method implementing residual rotation technique. method suitable CLNRM.  get predictions null residual plots, one can use null_vss() method. keep_null_dat keep_null_plot tells method whether preserve null residuals null residuals plots result. models needs use null generating method rotate_resid(), function can provided via null_method argument. parameter provided function fitted_mod, fitted model object. return data frame two columns .fitted .resid fitted values null residuals respectively. want measure variation visual signal strength residual plot, can use boot_vss() method get bootstrapped visual signal strength. method resamples observations replacement refitt regression model. Similarly, keep_boot_dat keep_boot_plot tells method whether preserve bootstrapped residuals plots. run comprehensive check including analysis null residuals bootstrapped residuals, use check() method. check result stored check_result attribute. summary plot can drawn summary_plot() method. solid line 95% sample quantile visual signal strength predicted null residual plots. dot line visual signal strength predicted original residual plot. blue density curve indicates distribution visual signal strength predicted null residual plots. red density curve indicates distribution visual signal strength predicted bootstrapped residual plots. p-value obtained computing ratio null visual signal strength greater equal observed visual signal strength. red area along solid line indicates often fitted model considered incorrectly specified data can repetitively drawn data generating process. example, H0 rejected small p-value. can also observed almost time refitted models considered incorrectly specified, clear rejection. Furthermore, since two density curves different , unlikely original residuals distribution null residuals.
code: keras_mod <- get_keras_model("vss_phn_32") set.seed(10086) dgp_mod <- visage::poly_model(x = visage::rand_uniform(-1, 1), sigma = 1) this_dat <- dgp_mod$gen(300) this_mod <- lm(y ~ x, data = this_dat) ggplot() +   geom_point(aes(this_mod$fitted.values, this_mod$residuals)) +   xlab("Fitted values") +   ylab("Residuals") checker <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = this_mod, keras_mod = keras_mod) checker$plot_resid() checker$vss() #> ✔ Predict visual signal strength for 1 image. #> [1] 3.474873 checker$rotate_resid() %>%   checker$plot_resid() checker$null_vss(20L,                   keep_null_dat = FALSE,                   keep_null_plot = FALSE) #> ✔ Generate null data. #> ✔ Generate null plots. #> ✔ Compute auxilary inputs. #> ✔ Predict visual signal strength for 20 images. #> # A tibble: 20 × 1 #>      vss #>    <dbl> #>  1 1.54  #>  2 2.36  #>  3 1.89  #>  4 1.15  #>  5 1.12  #>  6 0.944 #>  7 1.55  #>  8 1.34  #>  9 0.791 #> 10 1.02  #> 11 1.06  #> 12 0.943 #> 13 1.24  #> 14 0.918 #> 15 1.26  #> 16 0.958 #> 17 0.744 #> 18 1.04  #> 19 0.967 #> 20 1.44 checker$boot_vss(20L,                   keep_boot_dat = FALSE,                   keep_boot_plot = FALSE) #> ✔ Generate bootstrapped data. #> ✔ Generate bootstrapped plots. #> ✔ Compute auxilary inputs. #> ✔ Predict visual signal strength for 20 images. #> # A tibble: 20 × 1 #>      vss #>    <dbl> #>  1  3.01 #>  2  3.57 #>  3  3.20 #>  4  3.67 #>  5  3.24 #>  6  3.05 #>  7  2.90 #>  8  3.73 #>  9  3.40 #> 10  4.07 #> 11  3.43 #> 12  3.11 #> 13  3.24 #> 14  3.79 #> 15  3.59 #> 16  4.01 #> 17  3.73 #> 18  3.78 #> 19  3.68 #> 20  3.17 checker$check(null_draws = 200L, boot_draws = 200L) str(checker$check_result) #> List of 8 #>  $ null           : tibble [200 × 1] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   ..$ vss: num [1:200] 0.758 0.971 3.472 0.84 0.812 ... #>  $ boot           : tibble [200 × 1] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>   ..$ vss: num [1:200] 3.55 4.14 3.56 2.93 3.66 ... #>  $ vss            : num 3.47 #>  $ p_value        : num 0.005 #>  $ boot_p_value   : num 0 #>  $ boot_likelihood: Named num 1.22 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "boot_likelihood" #>  $ null_likelihood: Named num 0.0503 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "null_likelihood" #>  $ lr_ratio       : Named num 24.3 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "lr_ratio" checker$summary_plot()

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..
text: fitted_mod Model. model object, e.g. lm. keras_mod Keras model. trained computer vision model. dat Data frame. data used fit model. node_index Integer. index indicating node output layer contains visual signal strength. particularly useful keras model one output nodes.

text: Return object .

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) my_vi #>  #> ── <AUTO_VI object> #> Status: #>  - Fitted model: lm #>  - Keras model: UNKNOWN #>     - Output node index: 1 #>  - Result: UNKNOWN

AUTO_VI$..str..() #> [1] "<AUTO_VI class>"  my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) my_vi$..str..() #> [1] "<AUTO_VI object>

what: Compute auxiliary variables for the keras model — AUTO_VI$auxiliary
title: Compute auxiliary variables for the keras model — AUTO_VI$auxiliary
text: function computes vector auxiliary variables including monotonic measure (measure_monotonic), sparse measure (measure_sparse), splines measure (measure_splines), striped measure (measure_striped), number observation (n). Scagnostics computed using cassowaryr::sc_monotonic(), cassowaryr::sc_sparse2(), cassowaryr::sc_splines(), cassowaryr::sc_striped(). wish calculate additional auxiliary variables keras model, please override method. Ensure accepts data frame columns named .fitted .resid input returns vector values.

title: Compute auxiliary variables for the keras model — AUTO_VI$auxiliary
code: AUTO_VI$auxiliary(dat = seflf$get_fitted_and_resid())

title: Compute auxiliary variables for the keras model — AUTO_VI$auxiliary
text: dat Data frame. data frame containing variables .resid .fitted. See also AUTO_VI$get_fitted_and_resid().

title: Compute auxiliary variables for the keras model — AUTO_VI$auxiliary
text: vector auxiliary values.

title: Compute auxiliary variables for the keras model — AUTO_VI$auxiliary
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) my_vi$auxiliary() #> measure_monotonic    measure_sparse   measure_splines   measure_striped  #>         0.1544745         0.5232189         0.1759544         0.6000000  #>                 n  #>        50.0000000

what: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
text: function bootstrap data refits model, predicts visual signal strength bootstrapped residual plots.

title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
code: AUTO_VI$boot_vss(   draws = 100L,   fitted_mod = self$fitted_mod,   keras_mod = self$keras_mod,   correction = FALSE,   jitter = FALSE,   factor = 1L,   dat = self$get_dat(),   node_index = 1L,   keep_boot_dat = FALSE,   keep_boot_plot = FALSE )

title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
text: draws Integer. Number simulation draws. fitted_mod Model. model object, e.g. lm. keras_mod Keras model. trained computer vision model. correction Boolean. Correction bootstrapped visual signal strength due reduction unique data points null plots. jitter Boolean. Whether use jitter() generate bootstrapped data instead sampling original data replacement. factor Numeric. See also jitter(). dat Data frame. data used fit model. See also AUTO_VI$get_dat(). node_index Integer. index indicating node output layer contains visual signal strength. particularly useful keras model one output nodes. keep_boot_dat Boolean. Whether keep bootstrapped data. keep_boot_plot Boolean. Whether keep bootstrapped plots.

title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
text: tibble 1 3 columns depending argument keep_boot_dat keep_boot_plot.

what: Conduct a auto visual inference check with a computer vision model — AUTO_VI$check

text: function conducts visual inference check computer vision model. result stored self$check_result.

title: Conduct a auto visual inference check with a computer vision model — AUTO_VI$check
code: AUTO_VI$check(   null_draws = 100L,   boot_draws = 100L,   fitted_mod = self$fitted_mod,   keras_mod = self$keras_mod,   null_method = self$rotate_resid,   correction = FALSE,   jitter = FALSE,   factor = 1L,   dat = self$get_dat(),   node_index = self$node_index,   keep_dat = FALSE,   keep_plot = FALSE )

title: Conduct a auto visual inference check with a computer vision model — AUTO_VI$check
text: null_draws Integer. Number simulation draws AUTO_VI$null_vss(). boot_draws Integer. Number simulation draws AUTO_VI$boot_vss(). fitted_mod Model. model object, e.g. lm. keras_mod Keras model. trained computer vision model. null_method Function. method simulate residuals null hypothesis distribution. lm, recommended method residual rotation AUTO_VI$rotate_resid(). correction Boolean. Correction bootstrapped visual signal strength due reduction unique data points null plots. jitter Boolean. Whether use jitter() generate bootstrapped data instead sampling original data replacement. factor Numeric. See also jitter(). dat Data frame. data used fit model. See also AUTO_VI$get_dat(). node_index Integer. index indicating node output layer contains visual signal strength. particularly useful keras model one output nodes. keep_dat Boolean. Whether keep simulated data. keep_plot Boolean. Whether keep simulated plots.

title: Draw a standard residual plot — AUTO_VI$plot_resid
text: dat Data frame. data frame containing variables .resid .fitted. See also AUTO_VI$get_fitted_and_resid(). theme ggtheme. ggplot theme object. See also ggplot2::theme_light(). alpha Numeric. Alpha dot. Value 0 1. size Numeric. Size dot. Value 0 1. stroke Numeric. Stroke dot. Value 0 1. remove_axis Boolean. Whether remove axis. remove_legend Boolean. Whether remove legend. remove_grid_line Boolean. Whether remove grid lines. add_zero_line Boolean. Whether add zero horizontal line.

title: Remove a plot — AUTO_VI$remove_plot
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) temp_path <- my_vi$save_plot(my_vi$plot_resid()) my_vi$remove_plot(temp_path) file.exists(temp_path) #> [1] FALSE

what: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
title: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
text: function gets rotated residuals fitted linear model. rotated residuals generated first regressing random noises original regressors, multiply obtained residuals original RSS divided current RSS. results rotated residuals.

text: tibble two columns .fitted .resid.

title: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) rotated_resid <- my_vi$rotate_resid() my_vi$plot_resid(rotated_resid)
